page.title: 12Blackvein Pit Disaster
page.content: On the 1st. of November 1860, there was a violent explosion at the Blackvein Colliery, Risca, and 142 men and boys, 20 of them under 15 years of age, were killed. The bodies were later recovered; some were burnt and charred, while others were those of people who had died of asphyxiation. Many of them were buried in a small cemetery, made especially for the purpose, in the middle of a field on the opposite side of the valley to the pit, adjacent to the canal and near what used to be the Greenmeadow Inn. The cemetery, enclosed by a very small brick wall, stands neglected in the field, with nothing to mark it since all the headstones have been taken away over the years. The last headstone, carved in Welsh, marks the grave of a man and his 10 year old son, both killed in the mine.
